awd_titl_txt: Conjugated Systems Containing Antiaromatic Cyclobutadienoids: Synthesis and Study of the Multifaceted Effects of Local Antiaromaticity
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project, funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamic & Mechanism B Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Yan Xia of the Department of Chemistry at Stanford University is developing a diverse family of carbon-rich conjugated molecules containing unusual antiaromatic cyclobutadienoids (CBDs) to control and understand the complex effects of antiaromaticity for future organic electronic applications.  Conjugated molecules are critical materials for various optical and electronic applications. While they predominantly consist of aromatic frameworks, introducing CBD antiaromatic motifs has long been sought as a novel strategy to achieve favorable molecular properties, but conjugated CBDs are previously challenging to access. The proposed research will generate several unprecedented series of CBD-containing conjugated molecules, new fundamental insights into the control and influence of antiaromaticity, and new types of conjugated materials. This project integrates organic synthesis, design and advanced physical measurement of conjugated materials, and computation, providing a highly interdisciplinary and collaborative environment for training and outreach at graduate, undergraduate, and high school levels for students at Stanford and from the Bay Area.

Carbon-rich conjugated molecules are of significant fundamental and technical interest for their optoelectronic properties and applications. Conjugated systems containing 4 pi-electron antiaromatic cyclobutadienoids (CBDs) have been challenging to synthesize, thus limiting the understanding of the multifaceted effects of CBD in extended pi-systems. This project will leverage the methodology that the Professor Xia's group has recently developed to synthesize several series of CBD-containing polycyclic conjugated hydrocarbons with different topologies, sizes of conjugation, conformations, and electronic characteristics. Experimental and computational investigations of these series of molecules will be carried out to answer the following questions: 1) How to modulate the degree of CBD antiaromaticity? 2) How does antiaromaticity affect frontier molecular orbitals, pi-bonding structures and conformations, optoelectronic properties, and carrier mobility? 3) How to tune these molecular properties of aromatic frameworks by designed fusion of CBD motifs?

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Carbon-rich conjugated molecules are of great fundamental and technical interest for their optoelectronic properties and applications. Carbon materials, such as carbon nanotubes and graphene, typically consist of six-membered aromatic rings or benzenoids. Carbon structures containing non-benzenoid structures can exhibit interesting properties and molecular behaviors that are different from carbon structures consisting of only benzenoids. Conjugated four-membered rings have 4 π-electrons, which induce destabilizing antiaromaticity. Antiaromaticity destabilizes the ground state energy and reduces the bandgap of the molecule, and can be used as a means to tune the electronic properties of the conjugated materials. But conjugated molecules containing four-membered cyclobutadienoids (CBDs) have been difficult to synthesize.

The Xia lab at Stanford University has developed a modular method to synthesize a range of carbon structures containing multiple CBDs. The degree of antiaromaticity of CBDs depends on the conjugated moieties that are fused to CBDs and the topology of molecules. Stronger antiaromaticity typically results in red-shifted absorption and quenched fluorescence. We have also obtained oxidized or reduced charged species of CBD-containing molecules. Adding or removing 2 π-electrons changes the bonding structure and converts local antiaromaticity to aromaticity as revealed by Raman spectroscopy and calculation, thus providing stabilization to the otherwise unstable charged species. The charge species are important state for the conductivity of conjugated molecules, and thus obtaining stabilized charged species will allow us to better understand and control electron/charge transport in large conjugated molecules.

Carbon structures are also more flexible than what may be first perceived by their seemingly rigid planar structures. Contorted carbon structures have captivated increasing interest due to their enhanced solubility and thus processability compared to planar carbon structures, rich chiral geometries that serve as structural elements for more complex three dimensional topologies of carbon structures, and tunable optoelectronic properties and functions. We developed a method to synthesize contorted carbon structures with defined topologies by regioselective cycloaddition to CBD-containing molecules. These new conjugated molecules have good solubility without any substituents and the continuous conjugation and close intermolecular π-π interactions would still allow high intra- and intermolecular mobilities.

Despite the challenges from the pandemic in the duration of this project, the importance and excitement of research on organic materials have been conveyed to broader communities. Amid the pandemic, when in-person outreach events were not possible, we have organized virtual outreach activities using Zoom to showcase scientific topics that are appealing to the public and pre-college students. Examples include tuning rainbow colors from fluorescent dyes, chemoluminescence, and adjusting the clock time for Vitamin C clock reaction. We have also broadcasted live chemistry demos and a tour of our lab during these events. In this past summer, we hosted a female high school student from Woodside High School, who completed a 8-week summer internship in my lab and acquired basic synthetic and analytical chemistry skills. The high school intern will function as a science ambassador and present her research experience and learning to peer students at her school this fall to inspire other students.

For curriculum development, the PI has redesigned the undergraduate organic chemistry lab to introduce synthesis of organic materials (azo dyes) and emphasize on problem analysis and solving. The PI has also redesigned the graduate level physical organic chemistry course to interface traditional organic chemistry with organic materials with an emphasis on molecular structure – property relationships and problem-based active learning.
